I use Ant to pare the tests out when building jars or docs..

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Kevin Galloway [mailto:kgallowa@...]
> Sent: 09 January 2002 16:39
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Visibility of junit test classes
> 
> 
> Good afternoon,
> 
> I have what I hope is a simple question that many experienced unit
> testers/ users of
> junit will have encountered but I couldn't find the answer in 
> either the
> faq or the archive.
> 
> I have a standard hierarchy of packages which have public 
> interfaces and
> package private implementation classes. I generate the java
> documentation and all is well - only the public interfaces 
> are revealed.
> 
> I generate junit test classes to test the package private 
> implementation
> classes. I make these junit test classes public in order that my
> hierarchy of junit AllTests can see them. [This is important as I want
> to be able to run all of the tests using one invocation].
> 
> Now when I generate the javadoc all of the junit test classes become
> visible and ruin my nice javadoc interfaces.
> 
> My question is what approach is normally taken by junit testers to
> either suppress the javadoc output for the junit test classes 
> or to make
> the junit test classes invisible/ package private.
>  
> Thanking you in advance for any help.
> 
> Kevin
